mn11:0.2.eng: The Shorter Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

mn11:1.1.comm: Multiple suttas (eg. DN 8, DN 25, MN 12, AN 6.64, AN 9.11, and AN 10.21) invoke the indomitable force of the lion’s roar, the most mighty sound of the jungle (SN 22.78:1.2).

mn11:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn11:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn11:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn11:2.1.pli: “Idheva, bhikkhave, samaṇo, idha dutiyo samaṇo, idha tatiyo samaṇo, idha catuttho samaṇo;
mn11:2.1.eng: “‘Only here is there a true ascetic, here a second ascetic, here a third ascetic, and here a fourth ascetic.
mn11:2.1.comm: The same teaching is given more briefly at AN 4.241:1.1, where the four ascetics are defined as the stream-enterer, once-returner, non-returner, and perfected one, and at DN 16:5.27.3, where the presence of the four ascetics is attributed to the practice of the eightfold path.

mn11:2.2.eng: Other sects are empty of ascetics.’

mn11:2.3.eng: This, mendicants, is how you should rightly roar your lion’s roar.

mn11:3.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
mn11:3.1.eng: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say:

mn11:3.2.pli: ‘ko panāyasmantānaṃ assāso, kiṃ balaṃ, yena tumhe āyasmanto evaṃ vadetha—
mn11:3.2.eng: ‘But what is the source of the venerables’ certainty and forcefulness that they say this?’
mn11:3.2.comm: Ko assāso kiṁ balaṁ is found only here and at MN 93:6.7, where it also deals with an unequivocal claim to superiority.

mn11:3.3.pli: idheva samaṇo, idha dutiyo samaṇo, idha tatiyo samaṇo, idha catuttho samaṇo;

mn11:3.5.pli: Evaṃvādino, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:

mn11:3.6.pli: ‘atthi kho no, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro dhammā akkhātā ye mayaṃ attani sampassamānā evaṃ vadema—
mn11:3.6.eng: ‘There are four things explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. Seeing these things in ourselves we say that:

mn11:3.7.pli: idheva samaṇo, idha dutiyo samaṇo, idha tatiyo samaṇo, idha catuttho samaṇo;
mn11:3.7.eng: “Only here is there a true ascetic, here a second ascetic, here a third ascetic, and here a fourth ascetic.

mn11:3.8.eng: Other sects are empty of ascetics.”

mn11:3.10.pli: Atthi kho no, āvuso, satthari pasādo, atthi dhamme pasādo, atthi sīlesu paripūrakāritā;
mn11:3.10.eng: We have confidence in the Teacher, we have confidence in the teaching, and we have fulfilled the precepts.

mn11:3.11.eng: And we have love and affection for those who share our path,
mn11:3.11.comm: This appears to be the only occurrence of sahadhammika in this sense in early Pali. Normally it has the sense “legitimate” (as eg. MN 90:5.4). The parallel at MA 103 has 同道.

mn11:3.13.pli: Ime kho no, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro dhammā akkhātā ye mayaṃ attani sampassamānā evaṃ vadema—

mn11:3.14.pli: idheva samaṇo, idha dutiyo samaṇo, idha tatiyo samaṇo, idha catuttho samaṇo;

mn11:4.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ:
mn11:4.1.eng: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say:

mn11:4.2.pli: ‘amhākampi kho, āvuso, atthi satthari pasādo yo amhākaṃ satthā, amhākampi atthi dhamme pasādo yo amhākaṃ dhammo, mayampi sīlesu paripūrakārino yāni amhākaṃ sīlāni,
mn11:4.2.eng: ‘We too have confidence in the Teacher—our Teacher; we have confidence in the teaching—our teaching; and we have fulfilled the precepts—our precepts.

mn11:4.3.eng: And we have love and affection for those who share our path,

mn11:4.5.pli: Idha no, āvuso, ko viseso ko adhippayāso kiṃ nānākaraṇaṃ yadidaṃ tumhākañceva amhākañcā’ti?
mn11:4.5.eng: What, then, is the difference between you and us?’

mn11:5.1.pli: Evaṃvādino, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:

mn11:5.2.pli: ‘kiṃ panāvuso, ekā niṭṭhā, udāhu puthu niṭṭhā’ti?
mn11:5.2.eng: ‘Well, reverends, is the goal one or many?’

mn11:5.3.pli: Sammā byākaramānā, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ byākareyyuṃ:
mn11:5.3.eng: Answering rightly, the wanderers would say:

mn11:5.4.eng: ‘The goal is one, reverends, not many.’

mn11:5.5.eng: ‘But is that goal for the greedy or for those free of greed?’

mn11:5.6.pli: Sammā byākaramānā, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ byākareyyuṃ:
mn11:5.6.eng: Answering rightly, the wanderers would say:

mn11:5.7.pli: ‘vītarāgassāvuso, sā niṭṭhā, na sā niṭṭhā sarāgassā’ti.
mn11:5.7.eng: ‘That goal is for those free of greed, not for the greedy.’

mn11:5.8.eng: ‘Is it for the hateful or those free of hate?’

mn11:5.9.pli: Sammā byākaramānā, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ byākareyyuṃ:

mn11:5.10.pli: ‘vītadosassāvuso, sā niṭṭhā, na sā niṭṭhā sadosassā’ti.

mn11:5.11.eng: ‘Is it for the delusional or those free of delusion?’

mn11:5.12.pli: Sammā byākaramānā, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ byākareyyuṃ:

mn11:5.13.pli: ‘vītamohassāvuso, sā niṭṭhā, na sā niṭṭhā samohassā’ti.

mn11:5.14.eng: ‘Is it for those who crave or those rid of craving?’

mn11:5.15.pli: Sammā byākaramānā, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ byākareyyuṃ:

mn11:5.16.pli: ‘vītataṇhassāvuso, sā niṭṭhā, na sā niṭṭhā sataṇhassā’ti.

mn11:5.17.eng: ‘Is it for those who have fuel for grasping or those who do not?’

mn11:5.18.pli: Sammā byākaramānā, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ byākareyyuṃ:

mn11:5.19.pli: ‘anupādānassāvuso, sā niṭṭhā, na sā niṭṭhā saupādānassā’ti.
mn11:5.19.eng: ‘It’s for those who do not have fuel for grasping.’

mn11:5.20.eng: ‘Is it for the knowledgeable or the ignorant?’

mn11:5.21.pli: Sammā byākaramānā, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ byākareyyuṃ:

mn11:5.22.pli: ‘viddasuno, āvuso, sā niṭṭhā, na sā niṭṭhā aviddasuno’ti.

mn11:5.23.eng: ‘Is it for those who favor and oppose or for those who don’t favor and oppose?’

mn11:5.24.pli: Sammā byākaramānā, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ byākareyyuṃ:

mn11:5.25.pli: ‘ananuruddhaappaṭiviruddhassāvuso, sā niṭṭhā, na sā niṭṭhā anuruddhappaṭiviruddhassā’ti.
mn11:5.25.eng: ‘It’s for those who don’t favor and oppose.’

mn11:5.26.pli: ‘Sā panāvuso, niṭṭhā papañcārāmassa papañcaratino udāhu nippapañcārāmassa nippapañcaratino’ti?
mn11:5.26.eng: ‘But is that goal for those who enjoy proliferation or for those who enjoy non-proliferation?’
mn11:5.26.comm: The topic of “proliferation” (papañca) is explored in MN 18.

mn11:5.27.pli: Sammā byākaramānā, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ byākareyyuṃ:
mn11:5.27.eng: Answering rightly, the wanderers would say:

mn11:5.28.pli: ‘nippapañcārāmassāvuso, sā niṭṭhā nippapañcaratino, na sā niṭṭhā papañcārāmassa papañcaratino’ti.
mn11:5.28.eng: ‘It’s for those who enjoy non-proliferation, not for those who enjoy proliferation.’

mn11:6.1.eng: Mendicants, there are these two views:

mn11:6.2.eng: views favoring existence and views favoring nonexistence.
mn11:6.2.comm: That is, the eternalists and the annihilationists.

mn11:6.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā bhavadiṭṭhiṃ allīnā bhavadiṭṭhiṃ upagatā bhavadiṭṭhiṃ ajjhositā, vibhavadiṭṭhiyā te paṭiviruddhā.
mn11:6.3.eng: Any ascetics or brahmins who resort to, draw near to, and cling to a view favoring existence will oppose a view favoring nonexistence.
mn11:6.3.comm: The sequence of operative terms here is allīna, upagata, ajjhosita. Normally allīna in Pali means to “stick to, cling to”. But read this passage compared to SN 12.15:2.5 where we find a similar movement of drawing close (upagata)and getting attached. The Mahāvastu in Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit features allīyati in the sense “approach”, “resort”. This lends a greater coherence to this passage.

mn11:6.4.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā vibhavadiṭṭhiṃ allīnā vibhavadiṭṭhiṃ upagatā vibhavadiṭṭhiṃ ajjhositā, bhavadiṭṭhiyā te paṭiviruddhā.
mn11:6.4.eng: Any ascetics or brahmins who resort to, draw near to, and cling to a view favoring nonexistence will oppose a view favoring existence.

mn11:7.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, te sarāgā te sadosā te samohā te sataṇhā te saupādānā te aviddasuno te anuruddhappaṭiviruddhā te papañcārāmā papañcaratino;
mn11:7.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these two views’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape. They’re greedy, hateful, delusional, craving, grasping, and ignorant. They favor and oppose, and they enjoy proliferation.

mn11:7.2.pli: te na parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi;
mn11:7.2.eng: They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

mn11:7.3.eng: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.

mn11:8.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, te vītarāgā te vītadosā te vītamohā te vītataṇhā te anupādānā te viddasuno te ananuruddhaappaṭiviruddhā te nippapañcārāmā nippapañcaratino;
mn11:8.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand these two views’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape. They’re rid of greed, hate, delusion, craving, grasping, and ignorance. They don’t favor and oppose, and they enjoy non-proliferation.

mn11:8.2.pli: te parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi;
mn11:8.2.eng: They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

mn11:8.3.eng: They’re freed from suffering, I say.

mn11:9.1.eng: There are these four kinds of grasping.

mn11:9.3.eng: Grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.

mn11:10.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sabbupādānapariññāvādā paṭijānamānā.
mn11:10.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping.

mn11:10.2.eng: But they don’t correctly describe the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping.

mn11:10.3.pli: kāmupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, na diṭṭhupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, na sīlabbatupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, na attavādupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti.
mn11:10.3.eng: They describe the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures, but not views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.
mn11:10.3.comm: Renunciate orders such as the Jains abhorred sensual pleasures, while the meditations of Brahmanical rishis depended on letting go all pleasures of the flesh.

mn11:10.5.pli: Imāni hi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā tīṇi ṭhānāni yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti.
mn11:10.5.eng: Because those gentlemen don’t truly understand these three things.

mn11:10.6.pli: Tasmā te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sabbupādānapariññāvādā paṭijānamānā;
mn11:10.6.eng: That’s why they claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,

mn11:10.8.pli: kāmupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, na diṭṭhupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, na sīlabbatupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, na attavādupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti.

mn11:11.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sabbupādānapariññāvādā paṭijānamānā.
mn11:11.1.eng: There are some other ascetics and brahmins who claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,

mn11:11.3.pli: kāmupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, diṭṭhupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, na sīlabbatupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, na attavādupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti.
mn11:11.3.eng: They describe the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures and views, but not precepts and observances, and theories of a self.
mn11:11.3.comm: Perhaps referring to those such as Dīghanakha who claimed to believe in nothing (MN 74:2.4).

mn11:11.5.pli: Imāni hi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dve ṭhānāni yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti.
mn11:11.5.eng: Because those gentlemen don’t truly understand these two things.

mn11:11.6.pli: Tasmā te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sabbupādānapariññāvādā paṭijānamānā;
mn11:11.6.eng: That’s why they claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,

mn11:11.8.pli: kāmupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, diṭṭhupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, na sīlabbatupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, na attavādupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti.

mn11:12.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sabbupādānapariññāvādā paṭijānamānā.
mn11:12.1.eng: There are some other ascetics and brahmins who claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,

mn11:12.3.pli: kāmupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, diṭṭhupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, sīlabbatupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, na attavādupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti.
mn11:12.3.eng: They describe the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures, views, and precepts and observances, but not theories of a self.
mn11:12.3.comm: The teaching on not-self is what sets Buddhism apart from all other teachings.

mn11:12.5.pli: Imañhi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaṃ ṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti.
mn11:12.5.eng: Because those gentlemen don’t truly understand this one thing.

mn11:12.6.pli: Tasmā te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sabbupādānapariññāvādā paṭijānamānā;
mn11:12.6.eng: That’s why they claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,

mn11:12.8.pli: kāmupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, diṭṭhupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, sīlabbatupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti, na attavādupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapenti.

mn11:13.1.pli: Evarūpe kho, bhikkhave, dhammavinaye yo satthari pasādo so na sammaggato akkhāyati;
mn11:13.1.eng: In such a teaching and training, confidence in the Teacher is said to be not rightly placed.
mn11:13.1.comm: Elsewhere sammaggata (“rightly placed”) is an epithet of the Buddha or other well-practiced sages, where I translate as “rightly comported”.

mn11:13.2.pli: yo dhamme pasādo so na sammaggato akkhāyati;

mn11:13.3.pli: yā sīlesu paripūrakāritā sā na sammaggatā akkhāyati;

mn11:13.4.pli: yā sahadhammikesu piyamanāpatā sā na sammaggatā akkhāyati.
mn11:13.4.eng: and love and affection for those sharing the same path are said to be not rightly placed.

mn11:13.6.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhikkhave, hoti yathā taṃ durakkhāte dhammavinaye duppavedite aniyyānike anupasamasaṃvattanike asammāsambuddhappavedite.
mn11:13.6.eng: It’s because that teaching and training is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.

mn11:14.1.pli: Tathāgato ca kho, bhikkhave, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho sabbupādānapariññāvādo paṭijānamāno sammā sabbupādānapariññaṃ paññapeti—
mn11:14.1.eng: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha claims to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping.

mn11:14.2.pli: kāmupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapeti, diṭṭhupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapeti, sīlabbatupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapeti, attavādupādānassa pariññaṃ paññapeti.
mn11:14.2.eng: He describes the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.

mn11:15.1.pli: Evarūpe kho, bhikkhave, dhammavinaye yo satthari pasādo so sammaggato akkhāyati;
mn11:15.1.eng: In such a teaching and training, confidence in the Teacher is said to be rightly placed.

mn11:15.2.pli: yo dhamme pasādo so sammaggato akkhāyati;

mn11:15.3.pli: yā sīlesu paripūrakāritā sā sammaggatā akkhāyati;

mn11:15.4.pli: yā sahadhammikesu piyamanāpatā sā sammaggatā akkhāyati.
mn11:15.4.eng: and love and affection for those sharing the same path are said to be rightly placed.

mn11:15.6.pli: Evañhetaṃ, bhikkhave, hoti yathā taṃ svākkhāte dhammavinaye suppavedite niyyānike upasamasaṃvattanike sammāsambuddhappavedite.
mn11:15.6.eng: It’s because that teaching and training is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by a fully awakened Buddha.

mn11:16.1.pli: Ime ca, bhikkhave, cattāro upādānā. Kiṃnidānā kiṃsamudayā kiṃjātikā kiṃpabhavā?
mn11:16.1.eng: What is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of these four kinds of grasping?
mn11:16.1.comm: Grasping is fully understood only when its source is known. Here the Buddha begins a partial treatment of dependent origination, implicitly connecting this to his special doctrine of not-self.

mn11:16.2.pli: Ime cattāro upādānā taṇhānidānā taṇhāsamudayā taṇhājātikā taṇhāpabhavā.

mn11:16.3.pli: Taṇhā cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kiṃnidānā kiṃsamudayā kiṃjātikā kiṃpabhavā?
mn11:16.3.eng: And what is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of craving?

mn11:16.5.pli: Vedanā cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kiṃnidānā kiṃsamudayā kiṃjātikā kiṃpabhavā?
mn11:16.5.eng: And what is the source of feeling?

mn11:16.7.pli: Phasso cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kiṃnidāno kiṃsamudayo kiṃjātiko kiṃpabhavo?
mn11:16.7.eng: And what is the source of contact?

mn11:16.9.pli: Saḷāyatanañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, kiṃnidānaṃ kiṃsamudayaṃ kiṃjātikaṃ kiṃpabhavaṃ?
mn11:16.9.eng: And what is the source of the six sense fields?

mn11:16.11.pli: Nāmarūpañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, kiṃnidānaṃ kiṃsamudayaṃ kiṃjātikaṃ kiṃpabhavaṃ?
mn11:16.11.eng: And what is the source of name and form?

mn11:16.13.pli: Viññāṇañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, kiṃnidānaṃ kiṃsamudayaṃ kiṃjātikaṃ kiṃpabhavaṃ?
mn11:16.13.eng: And what is the source of consciousness?

mn11:16.15.pli: Saṅkhārā cime, bhikkhave, kiṃnidānā kiṃsamudayā kiṃjātikā kiṃpabhavā?
mn11:16.15.eng: And what is the source of choices?

mn11:17.1.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno avijjā pahīnā hoti vijjā uppannā, so avijjāvirāgā vijjuppādā neva kāmupādānaṃ upādiyati, na diṭṭhupādānaṃ upādiyati, na sīlabbatupādānaṃ upādiyati, na attavādupādānaṃ upādiyati.
mn11:17.1.eng: When that mendicant has given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, with the fading away of ignorance and the arising of knowledge they don’t grasp at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, or theories of a self.

mn11:17.2.pli: Anupādiyaṃ na paritassati, aparitassaṃ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati.
mn11:17.2.eng: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

mn11:17.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
mn11:17.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

mn11:17.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn11:17.5.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn11:17.5.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
